The Impact of Multiple Parallel Phrase Suggestions on Email Input and Composition Behaviour of Native and Non-Native English Writers
https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3411764.3445372

I had read this a while ago but I was looking at it again recently. It's a nice, large study with a detailed analysis. Creative Writing with an AI-Powered Writing Assistant: Perspectives from Professional Writers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05030

Studies the Wordcraft system built at Google (I've heard rumors a demo will be released soon?) by having 13 professional writers work with the system for 8 weeks. I appreciated the scale of this study! The results are in line with my own work / just talking to lots of writers about this kind of stuff. Curious what they think about Sudowrite (a commercial AI co-writing system).

📑📑📑

1. The Enigma of Being Yourself: A Critical Examination of the Concept of Authenticity
http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1037/gpr0000157

Wow, amazing. Reviews and examines (and critiques) how authenticity is studied in psychology. Lots of interesting ideas; would love to take some and use it to study human-AI collaboration and authenticity.

last_post.content:
Can Community Programs Help Slow the Rise in Violence?
---
Across the US, governments are investing millions in local, non-police violence interruption programs that only have a few years to prove they deserve lasting support after the federal money runs out. The evidence for how well some programs work is mixed & sometimes elusive, not least because it’s hard to measure crimes that never happen.

Can somebody with deeper #technical knowledge of Mastodon/#ActivityPub help me understand how information is moved around?

My very limited understanding is that when a user publishes/sends a post, the message is first put into the user's "outbox" located on the user's instance. It is then pulled from there from all the instances his/her followers are located on.

In order to receive posts, the user's instance continuously checks all the outboxes a user is subscribed to and pulls the messages located there, into the user's "inbox".

The federated timeline would then be the sum of all the messages that the local instance has pulled from the various outboxes its users are subscribed to.

To create the local timeline, the local instance pulls messages from all the local outboxes.

A user's individual timeline is simply the list of all the messages that are put into his/her outbox.

That would be the default. Users can shape how their posts are pulled by changing the post's privacy setting.

Defederation then works by no longer pulling from a specific instance and not allowing that instance to pull messages from the local instance thus blocking all direct communication.

https://github.com/w3c/activitypub/blob/gh-pages/activitypub-tutorial.txt

title: Slideshot: Watching Prof. Michael Stonebraker, MIT / One Size Fits None - (Everyth...

last_post.content:
Q: Why are other DBs so slow?

A: as Dr Michael Stonebraker illustrated, most DBs spend vast majority of their time managing buffer pools, crash recovery, and locking and latching. #LMDB has no buffer pool, and its crash-proof design yields zero recovery time, instantaneous startup every time. Readers perform no locking, no blocking calls of any kind. 100% of its time is spent doing useful work. Nothing else comes close. https://slideshot.epfl.ch/play/suri_stonebraker

title: Marie Tharp pioneered mapping the bottom of the ocean 6 decades ago – scientists are still learning about Earth's last frontier

last_post.content:
Pioneering geologist & oceanographer Marie Tharp changed our understanding of the ocean.

When Tharp sought a geology job at Columbia University in 1948, women couldn’t go on research ships. Instead, she was hired to assist male grad students.

Back then, many scientists still assumed the bottom of the ocean was featureless. Tharp figured out how to use data to create sketches of the ocean floor. Her hand-drawn maps helped develop plate tectonic theory. https://theconversation.com/marie-tharp-pioneered-mapping-the-bottom-of-the-ocean-6-decades-ago-scientists-are-still-learning-about-earths-last-frontier-142451 #science #history

Something I & colleagues have taught for years, still an issue today:

Unless you are using a VPN that tunnels DNS queries, or using the Tor Browser for all browsing, or have manually set up alternative DNS over SSL/TLS (DoH) on your device(s), your ISP knows every single site you visit.

It can then sell &/or provide that information to any 3rd party whether transparently (under their ToS), or opaquely (under provision of jurisdictional obligations &/or other shadiness)
